reviewText:
The very first GRID was (and still is) my favorite arcade racing game. It had customizable difficulty, it had teams and sponsors and your really didn't have to be always first to win a championship (something that NFS Shift 2 had problems with). You could buy your own cars and customize it, so you can see how you progress through the game. And it was fun to play with AI, since it wasn't really good (i.e. cheating) or really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The game just really balanced between arcade and sim and did it really good.

Now in Autosport you still have customizable difficulty and same championship system. And it's pretty much it. AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that would just crash into you giving no ♥♥♥♥ about it whatsoever.
You can't buy cars (well, you can in multiplayer, but you'll be given a car anyway when you joing a race). Well, I know that you race with teams and sponsors just provide you cars, but come on, it's not a sim, it's 100% NFS-like arcade, so what's the point of that?
You don't really progress, you just comlete one season to unlock another and that's it (it gets really boring very quick. You know, the AI and ♥♥♥♥).
Oh, don't forget annoying bugs with resolution and fullscreen mode.

So after all I would not recommend Autosport (even on sale). Just grab Race Driver: GRID instead.

reviewText:
GRID autosport... what can really be said about this game? Lots, but long story short this game rewards driving skill.

You have to hold the line, work the throttle, and have the patience to wait for the moment to pass. The bs drifting advantage is over. Only in select situations does drifting help. So far as I can describe through play, this game by design cuts down greatly on the demolition derby that was GRID 2. The A.I. is definitely challenging, but that may just be since the driving dynamics are different from other GRID titles so passing wouldn't be as familiar.

The sound of the game has some notable improvements from G2. There are cockpit rattles in various cars. The engine sounds are satisfying, tires, exhust notes, radio chatter...blah blah. It sounds better.

One aspect of the game I am enjoying a lot more are the RaceNet challenges. Again the driving dynamics make this particular game mode great, they take work to complete with platinum medals.

Should you pick this game up? Depends if you're an arcade racer or not.

reviewText:
Since I saw this game was on sale for $9.99 today I decided I should write a review for people looking at this game. First off, I don't think I have ever seen this game go on a 75% off sale, and for the record I got this game for free. GRID Autosport is probably one of the best racing games on Steam in my opinion. The graphics are great, and it runs well on my average PC.

The career mode is very unique, with you playing as a professional racer who drives across 5 different disciplines: Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Tuner, and Street. Touring is basically normal racing on tracks all across the world. Endurance is similar, but the races are a lot longer and require you to manage your tires by deciding when to put wear on them and when to hold back. Open Wheel features open wheel Formula 1 type cars. Tuner events are drift competitions set into heats, and also time attack where racers begin in a staggered moving start and try to set the fastest lap speed rather than the highest position. Finally, Street is racing on tracks made in tight city streets with many sharp turns and short tracks. As you progress through the different disciplines you unlock new Season opportunities and get closer to racing in the GRID, where all disciplines are tested in one competition. For events you do not get to choose the car you drive, which some people don't like but I am fine with. The game is structured into racing seasons where you pick one discipline and a season with preset races and cars. Seasons can also feature a special event where maybe everyone drives the same car or something. When a season ends you can choose a new season from any discipline. The game will save your progress between events so you don't have to play a whole season in one sitting. For each season you can also choose a racing team which gives different challenges or offers which give you bonus XP. For example, improve your lap time, finish above 5th position, lead for a lap. Also, for most racing events each racing team has two drivers. You recieve a teammate with a description and stats (however I do not think the stats really have a great impact on them). During the race you can order your teammate to hold their position, push for a higher one, or just have the default balanced approach.

The racing itself is quite good, featuring a penalty system for infractions like going off track and gaining a position by way of that. There is also a replay feature, similar to Forza Horizon where you can rewind the last seconds where you may have crashed or made a mistake. For racers who don't like this feature, you can disable it, and you will receive an XP bonus. There are also other setting you can turn on or off that will increase your XP bonus or lower it. For inexperienced racers I would recommend turning on the driving line which displays the best path to take on the track and where to brake. Now, a lot of the times you can make big gains in races by way of road rage and muscling your way through the competition, I have to admit I do this some of the time. As long as you are on the track you receive no penalty, however if you take enough damage, your steering column, engine, or tires can be damaged.

The multiplayer is fun, one thing is that you have to set your Steam download region to UK-London in order to find matches. From what I've heard this will not affect your downloads and it hasn't seemed to affect me so far. Surprisingly the multiplayer features the rewind function, however it will only rewind your car while everyone else keeps racing, so its really only for big mistakes. By racing in multiplayer you earn money and XP and can buy new cars. There is no customization and the cars you buy are just for multiplayer.

All In all I think this is a great racing game and a steal for such a big sale. I probably would not buy this game for full price however, but if I didn't have it and saw it on this sale I would definitely grab it! Great graphics, good career mode, good multiplayer, nice music.
NOTE: This game like most racing games is best with a CONTROLLER.

reviewText:
Looks good. Has probably the most hateful AI in a game I have ever seen. They just smash into you. Their cars seem to knock you off track with the slightest bump, whereas if you hit them they don't budge an inch. Super-aggressive AI makes this game, which looks good and feels good, absolutely infuriating. Can't recommend it.

Still it was on sale. And it WAS fun smashing into my friend in split screen mode. I suspect it would be better with a proper wheel and pedal set-up, but I'm not going to buy one just to be whacked about by the suspect AI in this game.

I played TOCA 2 back in 1999 or 2000 on PSone. Loved it. Played it to death. Made by the same folks who produced this game I think. The AI in it were totally fine, perhaps not aggressive enough, but it WAS fun. How can 15 years go by and their game evolves to this?

I'll probably sink a few more hours into it, see if it grows on me, you never know. If nothing else, the time trials aren't affected and I like trying to beat my own times round a track.

Would I recommend it? -  on sale, perhaps. It hasn't made me want to look out for the next installment, that's for sure.

reviewText:
Engine-wise, this is the most optimized game I've played in the last 10 years. Everything is super light and responsive with gorgeous graphics on mid-range PCs, and with acceptable graphics on low-end PCs.
There is not enough diversity in cars, despite the many categories (even F1-like cars), but there are a lot of different tracks to drive on.
Music is annoying and generic, and does bad job at complementing such a beautiful game.
Car damage is realistic and affects driving in a major way - this is not the game to ram your opponents off the track.
For me personally, in the age of games that struggle on quad core CPUs and 2+ Gb GPUs to deliver mid-res textures and questionable lighting, the biggest advantage of GRID Autosport is how amazingly beautiful and lightweight its graphics engine is. Definitely restores my faith in developers.
I have not noticed any bugs so far, and I've played it way more than my profile shows, outside of Steam.
Career is a bit boring, or at least it was to me. Driving aside, a race pilot's career is not very interesting to begin with. But it does provide an extra bit of addrenaline to the regular racing experience.

reviewText:
This game finds itself in the middle between arcade and simulation. Multiplayer is fun and challenging, with lots of weekly online events, but single player campaign is absolutely flawed in its design. Physics is pretty good, car damage also, but after some time game starts to repeat itself. Multiplayer becomes pure grind, and single play becomes boring since you are all the time just a driver for hire, without an option to create your own team.

Visuals and sound are top notch, so if you look at the game from that perspective, this is very impressive one. This game has a lot to offer, but it also leaves a lot to be desired in many ways. Anyway, I reviewed it as a positive, since I still enjoy driving with my teammates in multiplayer, and chasing platinums in online challenges.

Good one, but far from perfect.

reviewText:
MY BIGGEST IN DEPTH REVIEW EVER! I previously reviewed Grid 2 and I will start with a familiar sentence those who read my grid 2 review will know. Codemasters, my dear old friend. I have been a loyal supporter since Colin Mcrae Rally 2.0, stretching from V8 Supercars 1, 2 (Xbox) to TOCA Race Driver 3 and even the Formula One games (My fave) Its only fair I review GRID: Autosport. In a nutshell, its an improvement over GRID 2. OK LETS GET INTO IT! Again I shall start with the cons.



-Cons
First the AI. Easy to catch, bloomin hard to keep them behind you. It seems there is a rubberbanding effect here where the cars behind get a performance boost when you pass, especially the top drivers (looking at you Westley). Rubberbanding provides a challenge to the player but it kinda makes it frustrating all your effort catching (even on hard difficaulty) suddenly goes to mud because the AI suddenly go faster. And on the subject of AI they REALLY get aggressive out there. For example in Open Wheel (more about classes in the pros!) It is supposed to be NON CONTACT. But they do not leave space, and I found myself getting spun when they slam into me in the breaking zones like im not even there or they re-pass on the inside and clip my rear wheels with their wing. THis is a long paragraph for a single con.
-Damage. This is a pro and con. Its more about the AI damage. They don't seem to have any issues with damage. I went the wrong way, smashed head on into an AI at over 200kph and sent him flipping through the air. When his car righted again he just continued although he did have a lose wing and cosmetic damage... he finished 5th... SO work there needs to be done.
-Multiplayer. Again... I cannot for the life of me find a public match. Inviting my only other friend who plays the game is ok, but sometimes hes not always avaliable to play. This needs to be fixed. It happened on GRID 2 as well.

OK CONS ASIDE!! Lets get into the really great pros.
-Classes. The best thing about this game. Different choice of cars. Its obvious not every one likes the same race series. I hate Nascar, I love Formula One. It is great to see you can choose 5 different choices, from Drift to Open Wheel to Touring etc. It is the best thing about this game, and it brings me back to my V8 Supercars years.
-Damage. Much improved damage on this game, parts come off, or cause your car to pull to the left/right, even lose a wheel, and manage to keep on racing (Put this in F1 2015 pls? k thx) although some pit stops would be nice/
-Career. A big con. The intro introduces you to the mechanics of the game with a 2 lap intro race which is good to get up to speed and you can select which class to start/end with maybe open wheel, or drift any category you want.
-ONBOARD CAMERAS. YES. DRIVING CAMERAS. T-CAMS. ITS WHAT WE DREAMED OF. AND WE GOT.
-Custom races. This is a great feature. Any class, any track, any team. Up to 3 events each with custom lap amounts, practice and qualifying and setups!!! Whats best is the first race can start from qualifying spot, but the second race can start from reversed 1st race position (finish 1st, start last, finish 2nd, start second to last.) Its great!!!
-Graphics. Only one word Amazing!

Overall a great game for any racer out there. Easy to use with my g27 wheel. HIGHLY RECOMMEND~~!!!

reviewText:
If you're familiar with TOCA Race Driver 3 You'll find this game very familiar. Several racing disciplines you can advance in  either one at a time or alternating between. Sadly no prerendered cutscenes of your crewchief congratulating you or mussy haired race enemies berating you.

Drives very much like a codemasters game - definitely not a sim and definitely a little floaty but the cars are a little more planted than GRID. I've only done a few of the GT races so open wheel cars or the upper end cars may be different.

Runs very well on Linux and easily the best naitive running racing game available.

reviewText:
First off, this is a great game, I would definetly buy it if I were you.

The physics model is a perfect balance of arcade and simulation, much better than GRID 2, which was like driving on soap. That makes this game very fun and playable with w,a,s,d and arrow keys.

The car selection is huge, you get everything in between hot hatches and formula 1. Touring cars, muscle cars, hypercars, you name it, they have it.

The graphics are great, obviously not the best in the world right now, but still insane.

The frame rate is very constant, I dont have the best PC ever, only 6GB of ram and a core i5, but it still runs at 40-50fps pretty much no matter what I'm doing. I cant say the same for games like need for speed.

The track selection is immense, granted, some of the tracks are just variations of the same track, but it's still difficult to run out of places to race.

Multiplayer is great as well, impact ratings keep all of the jerks out of the race and let everyone have fun without being killed by some idiot driving on the track backwards.

However, there are some flaws. For example, when GRID autosport says you are going to drive formula A, or formula 1, it gives you an indycar instead. Indycar and F1 are NOT the same thing.

Another flaw has to be the DLC, which has been a problem for all of the GRID games. There is so much of it, and none of it is free. You want an extra car? Better have $5 lying around.
This also effects multiplayer, half of the time the party leader is using DLC that you probably dont have, and there is usually no other party to join.

The cokcpit wiew is super blurry as well, not a big problem, but still something I want to point out.

My final thoughts? Still an excellent game. DO NOT listen to the people who say you are better off with GRID 2, ive played the game before, trust me, you want this one. Although I do recommend buying it on sale, the GRID series tends to be on sale more than most racing games on steam, so I was able to get it for 10 bucks. Also, if you are looking for a racing sim, go buy asseto corsa, do not buy GRID.

reviewText:
Perfect mix between simulation and arcade racing. Beautiful graphics, really low loading times and endless settings can be changed if wanted. You can play this game just with the standard settings from the cars or fine tune them yourselves.

I do recommend a steering wheel with pedals or at least a controller. I'm saving up for a Fanatec wheel with pedals and now  racing with a Xbox 360 controller.

I also tried lot of other racing games like Project Cars (to much of a sim for me), Test Drive Unlimited 2 (too big of an open world for me), Need for speed series (too arcade for my taste), but since I started playing GRID2 I was hooked. Thankfully that nice balance between Sim and Arcade is still there in GRID Autosport.

If you think you're not an arcade racer, but also not somebody who want's to play it too hardcore like a Sim, this is the perfect game

reviewText:
9/10

Pretty fun racing game!

I expected it to be more realistic when it comes to car handling, but it is in fact quite arcady and a bit loose. I am playing with a Xbox controller and the controls are not super responsive and direct when it comes to the steering with the L joystick, but it's acceptable. You might need to get used to it a bit in the beginning, after that it's fine.

The game has a ton of cups and challenges to keep you busy for many many hours (enough content). Even with the arcady feel it is actually quite chalenging to drive against the AI! So far as I have played the amount of different tracks is quite low, I played for 7 hours and only driven half a dozen different tracks (and reversed), also the amount of different cars and classes is quite low.

One really noticable quality gap in the game is the cockpit view. It is really low detailed in most/all cars and they made the cockpit on the lower part of your screen blurry to camouflage it. It is extra noticable, because basically everything else in the game is pretty solid and good quality.

As for realism I think this game falls far below the racing sims on the market. Even Gran Turismo feels more real (direct/responsive) when it comes to car handling, but the AI in GRID is way more fun to race against and the races are more custimizable then in Gran Turismo. I also don't think that this game tries or was intended to be a realistic racing sim, but an enjoyable not over complicated racing experience. And that it does quite well.

Overall I think this is a pretty solid and fun racing game and worthy to pick up during a sale.

reviewText:
I really like this game. Keeping in the arcade-game line, they added features from simulations, which is big PLUS for me.

After few hours I am really glad I got this title. Controls are very fine for me (unlike other reviewers... I am using X360 controller). Summarized - I like the game, online modes and the way the game feels. Most Welcome for me is ability to create Racing Club with your friends in game (applicable after driving YOUR car with Race Club livery). Honestly I don't use cockpit view, so wheter it is there or not, all the same to me :)

I recommend this game for everyone, who wants simulation-like racing, but with arcade in it (Honestly I hate games where you can set your precise gear ratios, angles of wheels and such... I am no mechanic, I am player). This is my view and in my view this game is 8,5/10 :)

reviewText:
Was Super Excited to get this game. And after spending about 5 hours trying to rewrite code because the game continually crashed on start-up, I finally gave up. I just built a brand new computer, (and the game came with one of the items i purchased.)
and I am even running an AMD R9 not a nvidia, where the problems seemed to be originating from.

It would get to the inital menus and then just crash out as soon as I would try to open a menu.

And it seems from looking around for answers on the internet and here in the forums, there is simply no fix, at all.
I might revisit this again in a few months if there does happen to be a few patches for this game, but constantly freezing up the whole computer is just not worth the risk.

Codemasters, I will not download or purchase another one of your games on the PC, ever.

-1/10

column24: if you hate street races you can always kick off the Endurance season if you fancy. A great kudos to Codies for that. column32: you are likely to end up rolling. Track bumps fit properly-made suspension works. If you go real quick on a staright and there's a steep lift on the track
column33: you may take off the tarmac shortly. If you go full YOLO out of a turn and drive over the curb you can be sure to be going to lose control of the car. Just some remarkable examples of how well detaled this game is.\n\nHandling confirms that the latest addition to the saga is still an arcade. It would be better to say it is a mixture between a sim and an arcade. Handling is not at all precise. At any turn you'll have to make slight drifts to get hold of the car because if you just lock the pad axle on a single position the car is going to oversteer as if it had been kicked from the tail by Superman. This is common through all the previous games. If you get the purpose of this handling's characterictics you'll believe you're a pro racer saving the driving line with corrections. If not
column34: you'll leave the game apart thinking it is unplayable. It's all a question of practice though.\n\nCodemasters warned that AI is so dirty in this game. Plus the amazingly-superbly-awesome new feature of radio interaction with your trackside engineer. reviewText: I have to admit that there is fun to be found here, but the game is still floaty as hell.  I honestly don't know what Codemasters is attempting to do.  With the first game, I thought they were going for the Forza/Gran Turismo market, which... they didn't succeed at.  With Grid 2, I have NO IDEA what the hell they were thinking.  So that brings us to Grid Autosport, which still doesn't seem to go for that sim feel, although it's much closer than Grid 2 ever was.  So if that's not the goal, this doesn't really feel like an arcade racer, either.  It just feels like a very pretty, but ultimately not-great racing game.  The entire series has an identity crisis, as if it doesn't know whether to be a sim or an arcade game, and that just leaves it teetering in the middle where nobody is going to be satisfied.

reviewText:
Despite there are wildly different opinions on this game, I find Grid Autosport to be a fairly enjoyable game with it's accessible yet fun driving physics, great content and a throwback to Grid 1 or even TOCA series that should set the foundation for the next Grid game. Grid Autosport also brings back the rather enjoyable multidisciplinary racing aspect of Grid 1 and TOCA series where the game features cars from exotic hyper cars, Australian V8 Supercars, Formula 3 Open Wheel, GT3s, drift machines and so on. The career is serviceable as the whole team management aspect in Grid 1 was axed so you are very much a driver for hire now which is disappointing to me. Personally, I would still recommend Custom Cup (or commonly known as Quick Race in most racing games) where you can choose to race with any car and on any tracks to your liking, considering all the cars and tracks are unlocked once you boot up the game. There are some issues with the game such as the poorly implemented multiplayer mode, AI that can be too aggressive at times and a lot of recycled content that some might find it to be a bit lazy. Still, with a revamped and improved driving physics, driving on tracks such as the licensed race track, Red Bull Ring in Grid Autosport is certainly more enjoyable than Grid 2.

I do recommend Grid Autosport to you if you enjoyed Grid 1 or TOCA series but was disappointed with Grid 2's direction. Or you are racing game fan who is looking for a fun, accessible simcade with tonnes of content.

If you stumbled upon this review on a sale, I do recommend you to pick up this game along with the Season Pass as there are some really enjoyable content in the Season Pass.

reviewText:
0/10 for incomplete game and too much 'launch DLC'

Limit on cars you can use in MP... BLOWS!!!!

Multiplayer aspect is either non-functional or dead- started up the game to not be able to join ANY servers if ANY kind what so ever. Don't even try to blame user error. I'm not doing any stupid fix that codemasters should have done. Bottom line multiplayer DOESN'T WORK. If the game advertises that it does have MP functionality that is a straight up lie. Look up how many people can't join any servers and stupid fixes and let that speak for itself.

Coming from a long time GRID 1 player (600+ hours) this game tried to address everyones outrage to how terriblke Grid 2 was. Welll... they tried but didn't listen to what the customers wanted. People straight up told them to copy Grid 1 physics and have a cockpit view. Guess What?

They screwed both of those simple request up. Cockpit view is a half ♥♥♥ low quality job that is laughable by todays standards. Driving physics are bad.. not bad as grid 2 but they are not enjoyable like Grid 1. I enjoyed driving in grid 1, The cars feel off and are not anything like cars in Grid 1 were.

Grid Autoport lacks the soul of its  predesessor, I feel ripped off they even put Grid in the title and tried to play it off like ohhh yea we understand Grid 2 was a big pile of steaming dog poo.. Here's grid autosport its like grid 1"

Except it's not.. GG codemasters"

reviewText:
Where do I even begin.  First off there is a horrible memory leak in this title that can bring a GTX 770 to it's knees in a heartbeat.  I can't even really play this game unless I turn off the FFB because my Clubsport Wheel bucks like a bronco and damn near tore my finger off.  It ping pongs back and forth sitting on the grid!!!

I would stay away from this title until Codemasters learns how to do proper input support and it's patched three or four times.  The developers are amazingly silent on the many complaints in the forum and every time they do pop in, they insult your intellegence with some remedial computer pointers.

The game is actually fun to play, when you can play it.  However the techincal failures are too much for me to bear at this point.

reviewText: I wouldn't say this is in the same league as other sims like Assetto Corsa, Forza Motorsport, or GT, etc., but it is definitely a fun little racer. In fact this game does do one thing better than any other racing game I've played, and that's making me feel like I'm the racecar driver and not the car itself. All other racers I've felt like a sentient car born with an urge to go as fast around a track as possible. In Grid Autosport I feel like a driver racing for my team and trying to get the attention of better teams so I can further my career. It makes winning more satisfying and battling it out against rivals even more intense. Get it while it's on sale and you'll be pleasantly surprised.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
8 out of 10

Grid Autosport is a great return to series roots with much improved graphics and sound then other versions. featuring over 100 cars to chose from (including DLC), from cars like Nissan Skyline, Honda Civic, Mini Cooper through to the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 super sport, Lola B12/80, and the GT40 mk1 spanning several motorsport types from touring car, tuner, endurance (the races aren't that long), open wheel, street racing and party mode (which is basically demolition derby). from those modes they are split into different race modes including drift, JDM, unofficial V8 Supercars (Super Tourers) using only the VF Commodore and FG Falcon and unofficial Indy Car series (Formula A) using the  Dallara DW12 chassis.

with 28 locations and 130 track layouts from street circuits and closed racing circuits (real and fiction) to chose from including,  Spa-Francorchamps, Brands Hatch, Mount Panorama and Indianapolis. also featuring day and night racing (night racing on selected tracks only). unfortunately there is no Nurburgring or Circuit De La Sarthe.

Features a new and improved damage system, enhanced physics and flashbacks. It is an overall solid action racing game but is still lacking in great and important features that would greatly improve the series like better AI, pit stops, dynamic weather, dynamic time of day change, rally racing, longer races and get rid of that dam cockpit blur.

overall I give it a 8 out of 10 for the great graphics, car selection and the replay value

reviewText:
OK So I am a GRID tragic, I played the first GRID right through career multiple times, got to Legend status online then started again multiple times, and thought there would never be as fun a simcade as GRID. So I had high hopes for GRID 2, eagerly awaited it while still churning out laps on GRID. GRID 2, put simply, was an abomination that Codemasters should be ashamed of. But then, to atone for their sins, along came GRID Autosport.

It is everything GRID 2 should have been. I feel like Codies made this game purely to make up for the god awful retch of a game that was GRID 2. But Autosport delivers the original GRID experience, but expands upon it in so many new ways. Better models, tracks, detail, and racing. It is deep, challenging, and fun. I am playing through Career on Hard and though I get the odd win here and there, it is a struggle. Which means the learning curve and difficulty is almost spot on.

The AI does not race like real racers do, however. They are way too aggressive, if you are on the racing line and ahead of them, they will hit you every time to put themselves on the racing line, often taking you out. It is a robotic AI, not so much a 'real racing' AI. But you have flashback, and once you become aware of how the AI drives and corners, you can work with it. It's not so bad as to become a real problem, plus as with all racing games, you can ALWAYS OUTBRAKE THE AI. I would love to find a racing game one day, where the AI throws caution to the wind and overtakes under brakes more aggressively than a human can. As with GRID Autosport, like most other racing games,  the game is won and lost in the corners, and who can outbrake the best.

Once day, a racing game will realise this - and adjust to the way a human drives - or at least, combat outbraking by outmanoevering or using [prediction, as a real human racer does.

But all in all... I love GRID Autosport. I use a Hyperdrive ockpit and Logitech MOMO Force wheel and pedals. Sometimes I will even put my motorbike helmet and gloves on to race. I'm that much of an e-racing Nerd. But I don't care.

Thanks Codemasters, for delivering on the GRID Legacy. Just a shame you didn't also deliver it to next gen consoles.  Cause in a month or two, it's gonna be all about Project Cars and the Legacy of GRID will fade again. Until then, I'm still a Legend in my own Garage.

reviewText: The game looks good cars handles well, my wheel drive force pro it instantly reconised and was easy to setup and customise, where the game fell short is the Ai and optimisation, Ai is a bit stupid and tend to follow its path (not finding it ) they push you aggresively in the tarmac if u get in their way wich tend to happen all the time since it is a race!\nit it true that my rig is very old, but i manage to run some similar games with ease, my gpu crash after 2 races often, even at the lowest setting possible, i know there is a handfull of cars in the race 16-20 to render but it seems like every car is a standalone object , even if they look the same and drive the same ( dunno if devs use instances). last, the cockpits views are just horrible. as for the multiplayer , did nt got the time to test it, not really a fan of having a bsod every now and then, and restart my pc. overall i recommand the game but only if u have the recommanded requirements, and certainly at a sale, definitely not worth the full price.

reviewText:
One of the best [of the newest] racing games on the market. Has a nice mix of both arcade and simulation racing styles, mixes them together well. My only few problems with this game is how they have removed the option to create your own team in career mode, and you can only do this in multiplayer - which just insn't enough in my opinion. Also, dashcam/first person is absolutely awful.

Other than that, a great racing game. In short, it's better than GRID 2 but not as good as GRID 1. More or less what I expected.


7.5/10 - great fun none the less. Would recommend over other racing games on the market.

reviewText:
GRID Autosport is a very good game yet there's something missing from it. It could be because we've seen it all before, as there's nothing majorly brand new to the series in this game, however it does feel more like the original GRID than GRID 2. Which is a good thing for the original GRID's fans. A lot of tracks are repeated from GRID 1 & 2, but that's not a bad thing as most of these are the 'good' tracks including the made up San Francisco and Chicago one's.

There's a nice selection of cars in game which beats its predecessors, I think, by quite a bit. A nice bit of variety, but no way near the amount of vehicles that you'd get in Forza or Gran Turismo. Then again there isn't really any need for that many. The handling of the cars is more similar to the original GRID with that essence of both arcade and simulation (GRID 2's was arcade) however it does lean more on the simulation side a bit more this time. This game was made in about a year as it came out due to complaints from the original GRID's fans. Oh it also has in- car cam in it now, more about that below in the Pro's & Con's bit:

Pro's:
Nice variety of cars/ disciplines- Touring Cars- Street Racers- Open Wheel & more.
Graphics- As always, great graphics from Codemasters. Sharp and shiny.
Lot's of tracks- Whether they be made up or real life, you will find a track that you like.
Online- Is (I think) better than the Career mode. You can look up or set up custom sessions. But if you can't be bothered looking through things let it plough you face first in to a mixture of races! You can also be in clubs and change car skins/ livery's whatever you want to call it.
Menu- I like the menu's
Handling- I think it's pretty damn good, no more drifting in every single car like in GRID 2.

Con's:
Music- Lack's music. GRID 1 & 2 had more variety and had a big part in the games.
In- car cam- It's there, it's just blurry. There's also a dashboard cam. I'm not too bothered about it, I just don't get why they would have a good one in GRID 1 and not its sequels.
Repeat tracks- Only bad for people who have played the other GRID's and want something new.
AI- This one was difficult, they're nice and aggressive, but you can't help but feel they have the upper- hand some of the time. It's difficult to spin them out, but it's easy for them to do it to you.
Career- A bit bland the further you go in to it, plus having a teamate makes you not want to have one. Also you can't make your own livery's.

reviewText:
Great game!

Highly recommended by me!

The point of the game is to win the race, earn money, buy new cars win races and etc. The multiplayer functionality works amazing!

A downside is the interior view. It is blurred. They apparently blurred it so that when you race all you see is out the window and not the car. This is very good concept but it failed. Even when the car is stationary the interior is out of focus. The sad part is that they did spend time making the interior as it is HD from outside. I would have thought that because it failed they would remove it so that I would want to play First Person. Now I just use the hoods camera view instead.

reviewText: I like the GRID series a lot, and I'm not really into racing games in general. This series always feels like a throwback game to a lot of people, myself included. It's a solid game, and certainly worth the price. I've played a lot of GRID 2, so I'm sure I'll enjoy this one as well. It's not a huge leap different from G2, from what I've seen so far. Buy it. You won't regret it, especially considering it's a bargain at this price.

reviewText: I couldn't decide if I wanted to recommend this game or not? After playing some racing sims, I started to not like this game as much; however, I can't say it's a bad game because other games are better, that'd be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ review. The game itself is fun and challenging, but it's very arcade-like. More realistic than the other Grid games in the way that everyone's cars go the same speed, but it still doesn't feel like a sim, although it doesn't intend to be. So if you like arcade racing games, it's a gem, but if you prefer the realism from racing sims and are used to that, I don't recommend this.

Con's:
Music- Lack's music. GRID 1 & 2 had more variety and had a big part in the games.
In- car cam- It's there, it's just blurry. There's also a dashboard cam. I'm not too bothered about it, I just don't get why they would have a good one in GRID 1 and not its sequels.
Repeat tracks- Only bad for people who have played the other GRID's and want something new.
AI- This one was difficult, they're nice and aggressive, but you can't help but feel they have the upper- hand some of the time. It's difficult to spin them out, but it's easy for them to do it to you.
Career- A bit bland the further you go in to it, plus having a teamate makes you not want to have one. Also you can't make your own livery's.

reviewText:

Other than that, a great racing game. In short, it's better than GRID 2 but not as good as GRID 1. More or less what I expected.


7.5/10 - great fun none the less. Would recommend over other racing games on the market.

reviewText:
8 out of 10

Grid Autosport is a great return to series roots with much improved graphics and sound then other versions. featuring over 100 cars to chose from (including DLC), from cars like Nissan Skyline, Honda Civic, Mini Cooper through to the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 super sport, Lola B12/80, and the GT40 mk1 spanning several motorsport types from touring car, tuner, endurance (the races aren't that long), open wheel, street racing and party mode (which is basically demolition derby). from those modes they are split into different race modes including drift, JDM, unofficial V8 Supercars (Super Tourers) using only the VF Commodore and FG Falcon and unofficial Indy Car series (Formula A) using the  Dallara DW12 chassis.

with 28 locations and 130 track layouts from street circuits and closed racing circuits (real and fiction) to chose from including,  Spa-Francorchamps, Brands Hatch, Mount Panorama and Indianapolis. also featuring day and night racing (night racing on selected tracks only). unfortunately there is no Nurburgring or Circuit De La Sarthe.

Features a new and improved damage system, enhanced physics and flashbacks. It is an overall solid action racing game but is still lacking in great and important features that would greatly improve the series like better AI, pit stops, dynamic weather, dynamic time of day change, rally racing, longer races and get rid of that dam cockpit blur.

overall I give it a 8 out of 10 for the great graphics, car selection and the replay value

reviewText:
GRID Autosport, a petrolhead must have. The game is really long and entertaining. There are 5 types of racing (Touring, Endurance, Open Wheel, Street), but if you are like me, guy that loves cars, you will enjoy everything about this game. From powersliding cars in most badass ways, circuit racing, formulas and even drag racing, there is everything for everyone. Game is really fun and variety of cars is really good, from Retro Legends to Modern Machines, you have it all. Tracks are very good and very well designed. Graphics look amazing and cars look stunning. It has good career mode but I'm really enjoying multiplayer with my friends. We were having a blast. So all in all pretty great game, and if you like cars, what are you waiting for?
Verdict: Amazing
+ Good Amount of Cars
+ Real Life Tracks
+ Awesome Graphics
+ All Kinds of Driving: Racing, Drifting, Drag... etc
+ Tough Opponents
+ Multiplayer
+ Car Customization

reviewText:
Codemasters have done something good with this game. The tracks, the cars, the gameplay - all great.

The different classes of race and cups, the simple increase of level of each class and the selection of sponsors give this game a good linear direction. Something which was missing in Grid 2, which was all over the place like a crazy woman's makeup.

The upgrades on the cars are a bit restrictive, as it the setup on some sponsor cars, but having no control over that makes for good playability as you need to adjust your driving style for the car. And I like that.

Graphics are nice maxed out, some dodgy 8-bit styling coming from building reflections on the cars.. But that's really just nit-picking. The engine seems to be a lot more polished and infinitely more optomised. A massive step up from G2.

Where the game falls down are, in my opinion, the strength of team mates and the audible names. 3rd generation of Grid should at least have more names than the first. I mean there are completely bizarre names on there, but Doug is still left out! *huffs*

All in all a great little game from Codemasters, but I just can't understand why they made this a full product and not just an epic DLC for Grid 2.

reviewText: I was surprised at how decent this was. Looks great, sounds good, and actually plays really well once you get used to the new handling physics. Handles more like Gran Turismo 4 than it does the original GRID, but that's not a bad thing, it's just different. My primary complaint is that all variations of every track are not open to every class of car in time trials. You can only drive hatchbacks on the Okutama Sprint Circuit, for instance. The Grand Circuit is not an option. The menus are nice and sleek, too. I'd rarely make a point of that sort of thing, but it impressed me a lot for some reason.\n\nIt's a good game. So far, everything I've driven has been fun to drive, from Open Wheel, to Street, to Tuner, which I can't say for the original GRID (some of the EU and US events weren't very good). Just don't go into it expecting something which is exactly the same as GRID 2, or something that behaves like a proper simulator.

reviewText:
GRID Autosport, another racing game by CodeMasters, is aesthetically pleasing, and feels genuine.

GAMEPLAY:Like I've said, this game is very difficult; partners, they're more than useless, so be prepared to carry your 'mate, as I know I had to. The physics in this game are nice, you have to slow down/stop at the right point (something that can't really be said about the NfS series). Drifting is not non-existant, however, it's just not used much, due to the maps. Some of the vehicles (mainly trucks) are a real pain to play with, as the bars get in your way, due to this, you can't see much.

STORY:You, the driver, are paired with a sponsor; sponsors work like you'd think. Each sponsor gives different benefits, you pick the one that you think would benefit you the most. Once you've picked your main sponsor, you're thrown into the amazing world of GRID. Race until you've gotten to 'Level 5' of your sponsor, do this until you've done so with the other sponsors (Level 3 is needed for the GRID Prix). If you do too well, the co-host will tell you to turn it up, assuming you're playing on a lower level.

GRAPHICS:Let's get this clear; the game is not the best in terms of graphics (like Project Cars), but it is aesthetically pleasing to the eye. The graphics are by no means bad, hell, they've implemented 4k support (thanks CM).

OVERALL:
A racing game for enthusiasts, or for fans of racing games. Winning feels like more like a reward, rather than just text on a screen. Gives a challenge, and the difficulty settings allow for even more of a challenge. There ARE few cons (that I can see), such as white line penalties, small selection of music, optimization could have been better, the prices ($40 for this, I can't say it's worth that much), so forth.

9/10
This game is FUN, however: the vehicles are clunky, making it hard to maneuver, the DLC shouldn't be here (...no), lack of weather effects (snow, rain, lightning, the like), etc. It DOES get the racing part mostly right, it doesn't jeer off, and it does feel genuine.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Ok. Look, here's how it is. Grid autosport is a beautifal game. The racing is pretty fun and more challenging than I was expecting, which is good. Unlike most games you aren't expected to win first every time and 4th-8th is acceptable for most starting racing contracts. You start off racing small class c touring cars so Ford Focus, Honda Civics and the like and then proceed into other classes. I haven't got to them all so I won't comment on that. I guarantee one of the ones around this will have.

And whilst the UI is beautifal and well the whole game is beautifal, this WHOLE game feels like an after thought. I mean for starters when I first opened the game it felt empty, something was missing. I don't know what to say about it really. It lacks immersion maybe? And one of the most shocking things out of the box was that you HAD TO MAP IN XBOX 360 CONTROLS! WTF CODEMASTERS!!

Instead of a cockpit you have the cockpit kind of blurred out, and it's modelled horribly in there. No dials in there work etc. Honestly one of the worst things I have ever seen and I want to slap whoever at codemasters thought that was ok. Because it isn't. It gives a nice effect I get that, but at the same time it is horrible and i hope i never see it in a game EVER again. THAT is one of the biggest gripes I have ever had with a game.

Apart from that it's pretty good, and seems to be sponsored by Intel HD Graphics weirdly enough so i am curious to see how well it might run on my new macbook air (in bootcamp obvs).

Should you get this game though... well here's how I am going to lay this out. If you play A LOT of racing games you probably won't have an issue here. If you're like me who plays them occasionally you might enjoy it. If you like forza motorsport 4 and 5 well you will enjoy it but you cannot mess around and tune stock cars as much as you can on forza. This game needs to be taken seriously. And finally if you want this game as kind of SERIOUS simulator like i did save your money for project cars or assetto corsa.

Don't get me wrong this is a nice game, but for some reason it's just not completely for me.

No game has really come out for PC with the kind of arcade / simulation style of Gran Turismo and Forza and thats really starting to bug me. I like forza because if i dont want to play career mode, i can just buy cars, tune them and play online and set insane lap times (1.11.459 around top gear test track nissan GT-R, 7:49 nurburgring). Which is great because forza's career mode takes hundreds of hours to do, and I don't have that time.

After all this though do I recommend it... Well... If you can deal with the crap I talked about then yes. Else, save your money.

reviewText:
If you're expecting a realistic racing simulator, or a relaxing experience, go elsewhere.

Grid Autosport is very arcade-y, the career mode is well set up, and it's great fun to pick up and play, but it's not a detailed racing game for detailed racing game fans.

The AI is absolutely crazy, full throttle full contact crazy. If you're on the racing line and they want to be on the racing line, you're going to have a bad time.
The only way to get ahead is by forcing your way through. You either die a hero or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.

All in all, a good fun game to play, but not for the serious racing game enthusiast.

reviewText: The Grid series is about fun. I haven't decided if Autosport is better than the original, but it's doing it right. The AI does some wonky things from time to time, but so do actual dumb people online. Where it counts, though, the Grid series is really satisfying.\n\nGrid—1, 2, and Autosport (among other Codemasters games)—are enjoyable, challenging, and compelling. That's what I'm looking for.

reviewText:
GRID Autosport is by far the best racing game i've played.

What I liked about the game:
--------------------------------------

-The graphics are stunning, and can definetly be deemed as the best graphics to currently be implemented into a racing game. (Just don't open the car doors and you'll be fine!)

-The sound is sharp and realistic, and really makes the game that much more enjoyable to play.

-Multiplayer is a blast, and I have made alot of friends and had alot of fun in the meantime. Just watch out for drivers that don't know how to use the breaks when reaching corners.

-The singleplayer/campaign is recommended by me as it gets you to grips with the game, and gives you an experience that you will never forget!


Heres some tips for those critics out there:
---------------------------------------------------------

Don't like the interior blurry" view? Don't use the interior camera then.

Don't like the game overall? Go complain to a community that actually cares and go back to playing Mario Kart. WE LOVE AUTOSPORT! <3

Honestly I love this game
date: and I can't wait to see what else Codemasters brings us in the near future."

reviewText: ok, this is not an average review. i will not mention other grid titles. i am reviewing this game as a game in its own right. this game is not a simulator. if you want a sim get a sim. this isn't an arcade racer though either. it cuts a happy medium. the handling is somehwre between assetto corsa and nfs: shift2 unleashed. its very accessible, but very rewarding and has subtleties and nuances that will have you clenching ♥♥♥ cheeks and leaning in your chair. the racing is great. the AI isn't bad. a bit ruthless at times, but then so are you. the amount of different races is fantastic. plenty to do. the graphics are excellent, and it runs really well. no hitching or stuttering. no obvious glitches. menu system is great. joypad integration is faultless, and the cars handle perfectly well without having to fiddle with deadzones and gamma. you'll see no twitchy driver hands here thankyou assetto corsa. the cockpit view which seems in contention is fine. press the view button enough times and you get a set back view where you can see the steering wheel. its fine. overall i would rate this game a 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
Short version: GRID Autosport is a fun and enjoyable game; it has its flaws and little problems, but overall it's a very good experience and I recommend it.

Now for the whole review: in my opinion Autosport is what Grid 2 should have been. The game takes as its inspiration mostly the first Grid, with some features and ideas taken from the sequel and some new things to complete it.

GRAPHICS: G:A uses (again) the Ego engine. In my opinion it works really fine, the graphics are still very nice (especially with the HD textures pack) but at the same time scalable and lightweight; I can play without problems on my not recent laptop on medium-high settings without any problems. Sometimes there's a little freeze of half a second (it seems a common issue regardless of the pc), but happens once every 5-6 races so it's not really a problem. There's the controversial point of the cockpit view: it makes its return from the absence of Grid 2, but we don't have the detailed cockpits of Grid; instead we have non-functional instruments (only the steering wheel turns), hidden" by a blur filter. It's better than not having one
date: but it's quite disappointing (seeing also older games like Shift series having beautiful cockpits).\n\nDRIVING MODEL: it's known that the game doesn't aim to be a simulator. The game tries to be halfway between an arcade and a simulator
recommended: and in my opinion succeeds. The game is accessible enough
hoursPlayed: with a lot of driving aids like traction control
voteText: ABS

votesFunny: but it's natural in the game's system.\n\nSINGLE PLAYER CAREER: one of the most disappointing things of the game in my opinion. The scheme is: you have 5 disciplines to choose from

reviewText:
Grid Autosport...

I've got this game with my Intel I7 4790k... looks good , runs good but loads of problems

The AI ... as many other reviews have stated ... well , its not bad but its not great either , if you get in the lead , on higher dificulties , the ai will start smashing into you breaking your car , while it doesn't take any damage.
One major surprise i've had with this game is the awful textures. The spectators are sometimes zoomed on when you finish the race and god , did those PS2 graphics give me nightmares. And one extremely important thing that a '' profesional '' racer must have?  Well , if you're gonna include a 1st person view god f-in dammit include some hi-res steering wheel and speed meter textures? NO , of course , just more PS2 graphics , blurry as hell...

My verdict? Well if youre looking for a WAY CHEAPER AND BETTER alternative try Colin McRae's Dirt games. Way better AI and racing overall....
ALSO THIS HAS AN EXTREMELY BAD DLC BUISSNIES MODEL , STAY AWAY FROM IT

I cannot recommend this game to any racing game fan!

reviewText: The game is a lot of fun, when it comes to the realism, and is in many ways similar to Grid. Grid though, is somewhat old now, but believe it or not, the AI worked pretty well in the first game. In Grid autosport, that is not the case, they have somehow gotten worse. The AI takes no account for you being on the track too, AT ALL. The game is a lot of fun, when playing against players, but when I bought this game I had hoped singleplayer would be just as fun, maybe even better then the first one, which had me entertained for a very long time. The way the difficulty works in this game, isn't how good the AI is at driving, which it should be, when you turn up the difficulty, their cars are simply faster than your car, and impacts doesn't throw them off course, which it most certainly does to the player. I can only hope, since this is a fairly new game, that these things are problems they will be fixed through updates, this game could be so much more fun, and it would be a shame for this game to never reach the same level as the first Grid, because if not, this will be the last Grid game we might ever see, since no one can afford to very bad games in a row.

reviewText:
Grid Autosport is tantalizingly close to being great. All the ingredients are there. Impressive technical competency, a large amount of content, outstanding attention to detail in graphics & audio. But it fails at the fundamentals. The driving just isn’t as fun and interesting as it is in Gran Turismo or Forza.

In order to make a track racing game interesting over the long haul, the tiniest details need to be just right. Not only does the underlying physics model need to be complex, but it needs to be communicated to the player just right so they can instinctively feel what’s going on. The camera angle plays a huge part in this, which is easy to demonstrate in Gran Turismo. In Gran Turismo the bumper cam is the defacto way to play the game. The alternative angles, like behind the car, are all hilariously awful in execution. You can’t see properly where you’re going, it’s completely stiff in an almost unnerving way. When you use the bumper cam you can see the car rearing back, diving forwards, tilting to the sides, all in subtle ways which tell you how stable the car is, or if you’re about to spin out etc.

Grid Autosport feels simplistic. It isn’t complex enough, it’s too smooth. It’s almost hard to nail down exactly what it does wrong, because there’s plenty of great arcade racing games which aren’t boring. They’re usually much faster than Grid Autosport. Like the original Grid which met criticism from simulator fans who thought it felt like a racing sim sped up to 200% speed. I loved that aspect of it! When you drive down the same tracks in Grid Autosport at a more realistic speed, you’re given time to reflect on how nothing interesting is going on in the game. In Gran Turismo it’s engaging to drive slow piece of crap cars thanks to the exceptional feel of the physics. In Grid Autosport I’m struggling to be excited about the fastest cars in the world.

The career mode in Grid Autosport is easily 50+ hours long, and I will never finish it. The game isn’t good enough to hold my interest. When I first got the game I played it a lot. Now I fire it up once a month and play it for a hour or two. That’s the level of engagement I get from it. And that’s fine! It has its merits, which make it a nice experience. But when their novelty fades, you’re left with only the underlying game to carry it. That’s where it fails.

Despite this, I’m recommending it. It’s ok! Good enough to grab on sale. The first 10 hours or so are great. It’s only after that the tedium hits you like a ton of bricks.

reviewText:
Nope!  This game is offensively too broken to justify spending even $5 on if you intend to be chasing any sort of game progression or steam achievements.

Sure, the racenet site is pretty terrible, does a poor job of barely handling the minimal functionality required to support the features for which it is needed.  Sure, the AI and other humans are often out of sync between gamers in the same multiplayer game.  Sure, you will usually find multiplayer lobby empty unless you switch your Steam download location to somewhere in the EU.  That's all relatively trivial next to the known save game corruption bug that's wiped out my progress twice within 6 months.

Twice now, the game has rendered my save data corrupt.  Both times, this was after normal quitting of the game through the exit option in the menu.  This is apparently not uncommon, and has happened with a number of others.  None of the online racenet progress is actually stored online in any way that can be recovered.  Nor, for some reason, is the Steam cloud being leveraged to recover one's lost progress.

Some gamers have recommended  disabling Steam Cloud support for the game, citing repeated failures by codemasters to handle it properly in other games.  Further, it's been recommended that users go through the hassle of digging into their C:\Program Files(x86)\Steam\Userdata\<steamuserid>\255220 to save backups regularly.

After the first time it happened to me, I disabled Steam cloud support, and made a copy of the 255220 userdata folder on occasion.  I eventually got comfortable and a bit lazy, and had not backed up for some time, at which point it occurred again.

Hundreds of online races, purchases, upgrades, and funds lost.  Hundreds of career races and progress lost.  No way to complete the missing achievements without first redoing all the lost effort to get back to where you were before your save game data was corrupted.

I honestly think this game could be good if the publisher could be bothered to fix the handful of bugs plaguing it.   It appears the developer has no intention of fixing any bugs in the game at this point.  Though one could argue hours of fun racing did occur, resetting users' progress when they are halfway through the achievements... repeatedly... is absolutely not an acceptable situation.

Most active developers update their games with bugfixes as the need arises.  Codemasters apparently feels this game is complete, bugs and all, and is focused on putting their efforts into releasing new paid-for content instead of fixing the glitches.

I could say save yourself the money, but honestly, save yourself the wasted time chasing achievements, and save yourself the frustration and anger at a developer who took your money and doesn't seem to care that the game is broken.

Trivial lackings in addition to the above

* no choice of tires
* no choice of weather
* no choice of road surface (all tarmac)
* limited online garage slots prevent owning all vehicles

reviewText:
I have played every GRID game there was, and I have to tell that every one features quite a unique gameplay. In case of this one - I have to admit - by looking at the screenshots I expected a redone GRID 2. I was both disappointed and surprised, but compared to GRID 2 this game is a completely different animal. It looks different, it feels different, and most importantly it drives different.

Autosport is not a simulation yet, but it is definitely a hard game. In the beginning it's difficult to keep your car from sliding, and even Formula 1 GP racetracks seem somewhat narrow.  While the first two GRIDs focused on reckless arcade action with drifting involved even in ordinary touring races, here it's not recommended. You have to fight for grip, but after three seasons I easily got my driving style right with nearly no driver aids (I only left the ABS on) and no tweaking of my gamepad options (Logitech F710) was needed at all.

Probably the only two things I dislike about the game are the cockpit cam and drifting sessions. In case of cockpit most people complain about its looks. I actually liked the looks, but after three races I switched to hood cam and discovered that the game runs smoother. Is it a shame? Maybe, but TOCA RD 3 didn't have a proper cockpit cam and I didn't mind. In case of drifting sessions I don't like that it feels like a completely different physical model, and the car isn't that different from the ordinary racing car, which you use on different tracks - of course then they handle quite differently. Additionally I hate that drifting was embedded into series full of racing. In most series you use the same car for almost all races. In the first TUNER event I used three completely different cars. So this gave the feel that TUNER series is just o compilation of things which didn't quite fit other series.

Otherwise I recommend it. It definitely is a proper racing game, but no longer one for casual racers.

-	Doesn’t run as smoothly as GRID 2 on my PC
-	Cockpit cam
-	Most of the cars taken from GRID 2
+ Challenging and entertaining physical model
+ Lots and lots of my favorite racetracks
+ AI does mistakes again (I wish they implemented this function in Formula 1 games)
+ Most of car models are nicely redone

reviewText:
The GRID series of games from Codemasters is probably one of favourite franchises out there and I've been following them for quite a while, since TOCA 3 infact.

Where as GRID 2 appealed more to the arcade driver with less emphasis on realism. GRID Autosport is going back to its roots and feels much more like a simulator as seen in the TOCA series of games and GRID 1 ( if you guys have been following the series for that long, you will know what I mean ). The driving in this game definately appeals more to hardcore Sim" racer ( by bringing back cockpit view among other things ) and this game definately rewards you for that by giving you XP bonuses for driving a clean race without collisions.

Right off the bat
date: the game looks graphically similar to GRID 2 but there are noticeable improvements in car textures ( Free DLC to update car livery textures to 4k res )
recommended: lighting and shadows.\n\nMultiplayer is quite fun with you having to work your way up from the bottom. Each car you own in Multiplayer has its own milage
hoursPlayed: so the higher the milage the more the car will cost to maintain. 12 players lined up on the ( AI can be used to fill in the blanks ) all racing to the finish line. This is a blast when playing with friends.\n\nTo sum up
voteText: this game is made by petrolheads for petrolheads and that's why I enjoy it."

reviewText:
Almost as large of a disappointment as Dirt 3. I was lucky to get the game off ♥♥♥ for 10 bucks but that does not fix glaring problems I encountered in the first 3 hours of playing this game.
First off loading into the game, I setup my G27 and enter career mode. My steering wheel has zero force feedback going to it. Why would this be turned off in a racing game? Even after 30 minutes of tinkering I got a setup that was atleast driveable but sill felt disconnected After racing for a bit I only got further disappointed, handling is bleh, braking far too sharp and the worse part of this game, the AI. The AI is literally pants on head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or overly aggressive, with any contact resulting in bouncing off of them or you spinning out. Interior view has everything from the dashboard back looking like a camera lense with vaseline on it. No idea if the high res texture pack fixes it but I refuse to download a 3GB patch" for something that should have never been left like that in a title such as GRID.

The good
date: I really do like the option of having a second monitor display race information in a broadcasting layout. Would have loved it even more to pick what items to have up on the second monitor but I am not complaining there. I also like the benchmarking ability to better optimize your ingame graphical settings. Past that it is just another mediocre racing game that does nothing new nor does anything well."

reviewText: This game is pretty hit and miss. Gone are the GRID 1 days of building your own team, earning money, and hiring teammates. Now all you get to do is pick which team you’re racing for each season. And if you’re not racing for Ravenwest, prepare for your teammate to be utterly useless. If you are racing for Ravenwest, get ready for your teammate to try and kill you, because the AI in this game is set to M for ‘Murder’. The AI doesn’t even try and pretend to race cleanly. They will run themselves off track just to hit you. There are some good parts, the graphics are really nice, and the handling is better than Grid 2, but all of the cars are still way too happy to slide their tails out, especially in the Formula category. I can’t talk much about the online stuff, but the random challenges are a nice break from the monotony of grinding levels in each of the disciplines for single player. Speaking of which, you better enjoy all of the different disciplines, because if you want to complete the game, you have to play all of the disciplines equally to level them up and unlock the GRID Series tournaments. Don’t like Endurance or Street? Too bad, you won’t be getting any further. The last thing I have to say about this game is that I don’t condone the amount of DLC that Codemasters has started incorporating into their titles. The last thing I wanted to see was a Season Pass for this game, but here we are. Long story short, good graphics, meh handling, grindy single player. If you can find this game on sale and were a fan of GRID 1, go for it, just don’t get your hopes up.

reviewText:
I purchased and beat Grid 1 and had a pretty good time with it. Then Grid 2 was announced but they said they weren't including cockpit view. That's lazy as hell and I skipped Grid 2. Then Grid Autosport was announced and cockpit view was making a return. YAY! Just recently all of Codemaster's games recieved major discounts. I picked up Grid Autosport and gave it a try. I'm over 10 hours in and while the game is fun overall, there are a few things I don't like. The main thing is that yes, the cockpit view is back, but only sort of. The view is there, but the gauges are a static image, any car that has shift lights don't actually have working shift lights, and then the entire dash is blurred. The rearview mirrors don't even work and they, too, are blurred. There is also the lack of a field of view option.

There is also rubberbanding. It's the strongest in the touring car discipline. You can disable it by deleting a file but that file is tied to the game's anti-piracy system for some reason. This means that if you delete the file to get rid of rubberbanding, the game won't let you save your progress. That's ridiculous and pathetic. The AI is also extremely aggressive and will slam into you when you try to pass them. Codemasters wants this game to have some sim-like elements but won't include a full cockpit view and adds rubberbanding. It's like they want to make a racing game but also don't want to make a racing game.

There aren't a whole lot of tracks present but the ones included do look alright. The cars look nice as well. There's some DLC available (of course) but I'm not spending any more money on this game so I'm not sure how that content is.

There are some positives, though. The graphics are okay and there's no FPS lock. The game runs pretty smoothly. There's a few different disciplines and a decent variety of vehicles. Lots of input devices are supported and there's a nice amount of graphical options and difficulty options. The sounds are pretty good, from engine noises to crowds and track sounds, everything sounds nice. So while the game can be fun, I can't recommend it due to the half-♥♥♥♥♥ cockpit view and inclusion of rubberbanding AI. And I definitely wouldn't recommend it at its normal $50 price. Wait a while and pick it up when it gets to $10 if you really want to try it.

reviewText:
Like many others I was a huge fan of the original GRID. Like many other I thought Grid 2 was a huge misstep. Like many others I think this is even worse. Welcome to the new era of annual releases packed with day 1 DLC. I definitely do not recommend this game.

The career is a farce, in my opinion. You don't progress or improve so much as you simply pick a new team in between every race, and drive a borrowed car. There's no sense of ownership in your accomplishments; the online is no better.

Don't listen to what Codemasters says about listening to the community. It's all nonsense. The cars handle the same as G2, the career is infinitely more bland, the AI still attempts to kill you at every turn, and the online has no accountable match making system.

My advice would be to simply re-play GRID 1. It's still the superior experience.

A waste, and a squandered opportunity. This will be my last Codemasters racing game purchase for a long time. They've got a lot of work to do to earn my trust back.

reviewText: In my Grid 2 review, I complained about the lack of cockpit view. Said it was very 'arcadey'. But as you can see form my profile, I ended up playing it quite alot and enjoyed it for what it was... Anyway, I had high hopes for Autosport when I heard Grid 2's failings had been addressed based on feedback from the community. Cockpit view in this version and more realistic handling. A cross between sim and arcade. However, even though I havent played this much yet, I was instantly disappointed. Cockpit view is a joke, it's really blurry and you can't see the car interior or the gauges. The first Grid is better! I'll probably end up playing Autosport with bonnet view like I did for Grid 2. Need to start watching YouTube videos before buying games. Be warned.

reviewText:
I have played every GRID game there was, and I have to tell that every one features quite a unique gameplay. In case of this one - I have to admit - by looking at the screenshots I expected a redone GRID 2. I was both disappointed and surprised, but compared to GRID 2 this game is a completely different animal. It looks different, it feels different, and most importantly it drives different.

Autosport is not a simulation yet, but it is definitely a hard game. In the beginning it's difficult to keep your car from sliding, and even Formula 1 GP racetracks seem somewhat narrow.  While the first two GRIDs focused on reckless arcade action with drifting involved even in ordinary touring races, here it's not recommended. You have to fight for grip, but after three seasons I easily got my driving style right with nearly no driver aids (I only left the ABS on) and no tweaking of my gamepad options (Logitech F710) was needed at all.

Probably the only two things I dislike about the game are the cockpit cam and drifting sessions. In case of cockpit most people complain about its looks. I actually liked the looks, but after three races I switched to hood cam and discovered that the game runs smoother. Is it a shame? Maybe, but TOCA RD 3 didn't have a proper cockpit cam and I didn't mind. In case of drifting sessions I don't like that it feels like a completely different physical model, and the car isn't that different from the ordinary racing car, which you use on different tracks - of course then they handle quite differently. Additionally I hate that drifting was embedded into series full of racing. In most series you use the same car for almost all races. In the first TUNER event I used three completely different cars. So this gave the feel that TUNER series is just o compilation of things which didn't quite fit other series.

Otherwise I recommend it. It definitely is a proper racing game, but no longer one for casual racers.

-	Doesn’t run as smoothly as GRID 2 on my PC
-	Cockpit cam
-	Most of the cars taken from GRID 2
+ Challenging and entertaining physical model
+ Lots and lots of my favorite racetracks
+ AI does mistakes again (I wish they implemented this function in Formula 1 games)
+ Most of car models are nicely redone

reviewText:
How is GRID Autosport?
In my opinion, this is the true successor to the orignal GRID from 2008.
Where GRID 2 turned out to be a mere fun racer, this release is back on the right track.
It improves the original GRID in every aspect. And what it does is not only good,
but sets the standard in PC Racing Games.
Finally, I am able to trash Shift, Shift 2 Unleashed, Race07, GTR Evolution. etc.
All those RaceSims which promised everything, but GRID Autosport has it all.
Painstakingly I have tried all patches , whatever, to make those Racing Games worth my time,
where GRID Autosport delivers out-of-the-box.
Better handling, better graphics, better driving physics, better cockpit perspective,
and especially it offers more fun.
Codemasters really proves to be quite good at what they are doing.
9 out of 10

reviewText:
GRID Autosport and Assetto Corsa brings us PC gamers closer to that Forza Motorsport and Gran Turismo level of racing.
This is my review of GRID Autosport in the time that I've played it and I hope you enjoy reading it.

Gameplay:

GRID Autosport provides a fun environment plus intense racing to give you the perfect balance between Simulation and Arcade.
The driving model is very good as it's not too challenging but at the same time you can't underestimate it or else you'll be put into a wall.
There are 5 disciplines in this game: Tuner, Street, Open Wheel, Endurance, and Touring.
These 5 different disciplines all bring a unique selection of cars and unique gameplay.
This all works very well in making a fun yet challenging game that can give Forza Motorsport and Gran Turismo fans such as myself the same level of entertainment except on the PC platform.
Codemasters have made a huge improvement to their racing franchises (since the fall of quality aka. DiRT Showdown) by listening to the community and what they want in a racing game.
GRID 2 had a extremely arcade like driving model and lacked many features including interior camera, since then they've taken all the feedback and produced this great game.
AI is extremely well done, they know what they're doing (most of the time) and have proven to be a formiddable opponent at higher AI difficulties.
Also there are many many camera angles to suit anybody's preference.

Story:

This game features quite a flexible campaign to become the best at all 5 disciplines and become the GRID Champion.
It's pretty much the same as Forza in which you choose a series to do and then you do it.
GRID makes this concept more enjoyable by making you pick what team you'd like to race for the series and that team has objectives to complete during that season and certain vehicles picked out for you. You also get a teammate in that series (Beware, They're pretty damn bad) which you control their aggression through 5 stages.
Defend Position, Hold Position, Balanced, Push Position, Attack Position
This makes for very dynamic gameplay as you also have to focus on another AI's aggresion of the race and estimate their stress levels.
Each team has a livery for particular vehicles such as: Kicker's Volkswagon Golf Livery.
The real joy is in the Multiplayer portion of the game.

Multiplayer:

In Multiplayer you have to earn money by doing challenges and racing other players in intense races.
Normally that's all a Multiplayer is? Yeah but not in this game.
The real joy of Multiplayer is managing a garage of vehicles you've purchased and then making custom liveries for them giving a sense of personalisation and pride.
The higher the rank the more range of sponsors you can put onto your vehicle.
You can also make a Club of friends or strangers that has a custom made livery for all members to use.

Cons:

This game would be great if only these four things weren't on this portion of the review.

- Interior is poorly textured and blurred. Originally made so people would focus on the track instead of the interior making
a saddening atmosphere in the vehicle.

- No looking around the vehicle's interior. Another let down but at least 4K users get a great version of the game where
they can see all of the cockpit.

- Blurred out mirrors. The side and rear view mirrors are blurred out and don't actually work at all which is another
saddening aspect of the interior viewing.

- Not many people playing multiplayer.

I hope you enjoyed reading this review and I hope this helped make you decide if you'd like to buy it or not.

I give this a 9 out of 10
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't like to write reviews for a game if I have less than 4 hours of gameplay, but I'll do it anyway. (106 minutes when writing this).

If you're looking for a racing sim: this is the wrong game for you. If you're looking for a fun arcade racing game: you could try this game, but Need for Speed or Grid 2 would be recommended if you're an arcade racer. This game is in the middle of being a racing sim and being an arcade game.

You have to be able to control a fast racing car on track to play this game, but you don't need to driver super realistic. Sliding a bit trough corners are OK, but you have to fight cars in this game more than in Grid 2. I, my self, am a fan of the racing sim games, those were you have to hit braking points and apexes about perfect to have a chance, where sliding trough corners isn't the fastest way to finish. For me this game is fun to play, but not a game that satifies my racing sim needs. This game is just for fun in my opinion, not a game where you try your hardest.

AI may not be perfect, they love to drive into you hard or gentle, enough to make you annoyed at some times. ALWAYS be careful when overtaking or defending. The game still is fun though, but again: just for fun, not a game for the hardcore sim racers.

The game runs very nicely on my computer, with high graphic setting. Average FPS on a decent gaming PC with high graphics can be between 45 and 50 FPS, so its fine.

I would recommend this game, but remember: not a sim racing game for those of you who want that. Don't expect that. Handling is much better than arcade games though, so its not too unrealistic.
